Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2013 04:19PM dogsandjogs wrote: You will feel normal, but it will be a NEW normal. You'll appreciate everything more, not take things for granted so much, live in the moment as much as you can, get rid of people who don't make you feel worthwhile. You'll be more tolerant and less impatient.  Just wait and see---
Posts.Title: I'm terrified of the recovery room! SophiaMarie barbe1958

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2013 06:57AM dogsandjogs wrote: Don't do too much too soon! I felt so great after my lumpectomy that I straightened the house, made a bunch of phone calls, etc. The next day I walked my dogs --then on the third day I was exhausted. I did do some stretching of the arms after getting the ok from the surgeon's office.
Posts.Title: I'm terrified of the recovery room! SophiaMarie barbe1958

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2013 02:41PM dogsandjogs wrote: Bring a book or some needle-work. I always bring my crocheting to doctor appointments and when waiting for surgery. It helps a lot and usually other ladies ask what you are making and you end up having nice chats. Gets your mind off of things--
Posts.Title: I'm terrified of the recovery room! SophiaMarie barbe1958

Then I had to sit in the general waiting room (where everyone, male and female, wait before their surgery) and massage my breast to make sure the dye went where it was supposed to go. I had to massage for 5 minutes every 10 minutes for 2 hrs!  It was embarrasing, but everybody averted their eyes LOL
Posts.Title: I'm terrified of the recovery room! SophiaMarie barbe1958

Posts.Title: Pain in chest below left breast where lumpectomy was done dogsandjogs Annette47

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2013 08:37AM dogsandjogs wrote: After you hear the treatment plan you should set yourself a goal (nothing to do with the cancer) I decided to replace the roof on my house; after that I started training for a race; after that I joined a running club; after that I volunteered at an animal shelter; after that I decided to crochet an afghan.  You get the idea----plan your life so you don't sit and dwell on the cancer. It doesn't have to be anything major; it doesn't matter how small the goal is - just do it. You need to keep your mind busy so it doesn't think about cancer all the time.
Posts.Title: I'm terrified of the recovery room! SophiaMarie barbe1958

Posts.Content: dogsandjogs wrote: I went to the ER last week due to persistent (but minor) chest pains behind my left breast. I thought it was my heart, but they said no. I also had a chest x-ray which showed subsegmental "something" which apparently means a part of the lung is collapsed for some unknown reason. The diagnosis said COPD. Copies of the various reports from the ER were sent to both my primary doctor and my cardiologist. I am waiting for my insurance to ok a stress/echo, but neither doctor has mention the lung issue and it is possible they haven't even read the report either. The ER doctor didn't bring it up; just said to see my doctor for follow-up. I am wondering - could this be mets to the lung? How do they look on an x-ray? A friend has suggested I see a pulmonary specialist. Have not told my family as I don't want to worry them. I have no shortness of breath - jog/walk for several hours daily so how could I have COPD. It is a complete mystery----the pain is now pretty much gone - just recurs now and then when I'm stressed so this could just be all in my mind. Any suggestions? Thanks! Dx 11/1982, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/17 nodes Surgery 11/17/1982 Lymph node removal: Right; Mastectomy: Right; Reconstruction (right): Nipple reconstruction Dx 11/15/2010, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR+ Surgery 2/11/2011 Lumpectomy: Left; Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Pain in chest below left breast where lumpectomy was done dogsandjogs Annette47

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2011 12:08PM dogsandjogs wrote: Well, mine was pretty abrupt too. Introduced himself then said I needed a biopsy because he didn't know what the lump was!  I then asked if they could do it right then and both he and the technician chuckled like it was a completely absurd question.  No, you will need an appointment the tech said (as the radiologist walked out the door) the scheduler will call you. The biospy doc was very much "all business" and didn't say much either. The tech handed me a bunch of material to read and cautioned me to "not read the last 4 pages" as it would scare me. So, of course I did - and no, it didn't scare me. I have to think that these people don't like to give a cancer diagnosis and have to fight their emotions too -so they become abrupt.  So I try not to take it personally.
Posts.Title: OK, need biopsy. Snarky radiologist, too. iammommy janet58

Posts.Title: Question about detecting mets when mammo didn't detect cancer RosesToeses Momine

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2013 09:43AM dogsandjogs wrote: I began mammograms at age 40 and they were all clear. Then at age 46, I found the cancer during my monthly self-exam. After the mastectomy I told a radiologist 'I don't trust mammograms, they never caught mine!" His response was that it might have been an error by whoever read it and they were only 85 percent correct, etc etc and thefore it would be stupid of me to quit having them. So I continued ---until at age 74 I once again found a cancer during my self-exam. All those years of mammograms; uncomfortable, expensive, giving off radiation and yet they missed a cancer AGAIN. I have only had one mammogram since my lumpectomy in 2011 and am not in a hurry for another. I check my breasts every month though and as the breast center director told me "You need to do both, you can't rely on a mammogram alone." But I know women who trust mammograms completely and never do self-exam. One discovered cancers in both breasts, fairly large ones, and had a double mastectomy.
Posts.Title: Question about detecting mets when mammo didn't detect cancer RosesToeses Momine

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2013 06:54AM dogsandjogs wrote: My DIL has lymphoma. It began, apparently, in a lymph node in the groin area. That was taken out, she got radiation in the area and for follow-up she gets a complete body scan every year to see if the cancer has settled anywhere. So far so good! I think this must be a PET scan? So if all of us who have had cancer could get one of these every year mets would be discovered. But probably insurance would not pay! JMO!

Wishing you the best!  I'm a 31 year survivor and there are many of us out there. Stay strong!

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2013 07:29PM dogsandjogs wrote: I had a long wait, from my discovery of the lump in November to a lumpectomy in February. I was concerned too, but the nurse navigator at the breast center assured me that the time frame was not that long and not to worry.
Posts.Title: Scared... and concerned about delay of imaging lauramsd Ariom

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2012 01:21AM dogsandjogs wrote: Well. in 1982 things were different. I found a lump.Surgeon said to wait 2 weeks as he thought it might have something to do with my period. Still there after 2 weeks so he took it out right in the office. Turns out it was cancer. I had various scans; bone and liver and when nothing was found I was scheduled for a mastectomy. Had the mastectomy, 17 lymph nodes removed and reconstruction all part of the same procedure (took about 4 hours) Things were sure simpler in those days, no needle or core biopsies, no MRIs. I stayed cancer-free for 28 years (with NO follow up other than a blood test) then got a new primary in the other breast.  All the tests they did this time were exhausting, stressful and expensive. Still don't have all the bills and this was done last year..
Posts.Title: Can needle biopsy do more harm? Aruba domesticwomen

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2012 01:37AM dogsandjogs wrote: Yorkie Mom:  No, just a shot to numb the area. No pain at all. The surgeon was movie-star-handsome so that helped a lot And the plastic surgeon who did the immediate implant wasn't bad either!. Had one drain and   was allowed to go back to work after 3 weeks.  Then had the second stage reconstruction a year later. But I still have no surface feeling on that side; down to the waist and on the arm down to the elbow. They told me many nerves had to be cut so I wouldn't get feeling back for a few years. Well, feeling NEVER did come back.
Posts.Title: Can needle biopsy do more harm? Aruba domesticwomen

Posts.Title: sad, alone and confused Idunno Hortense

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2013 11:05AM dogsandjogs wrote: I had my biopsy while on vacation from work. In one way it made it more difficult because I didn't have work to occupy my mind. So I decided to get a new roof done. Then I cleaned the whole house. These things made me feel I was in control of something---and it helped a lot. After the diagnosis I returned from my vacation and scans were scheduled. Luckily I worked next door to a hospital so just went on my lunch hours for the 3 scans. Worked out great. Then I had the surgery in the same hospital a couple of weeks later. Since I knew so many hospital workers it actually made my stay pleasant. I couldn't stand to stay home for the usual 6 weeks afterwards so the doctor said I could go back as soon as the drain was out. So I was back in 3 weeks. I had a mastectomy with reconstruction at the same time. So for me, having to work kept me sane. I would have gone crazy sitting at home wondering if I was going to live or die.
Posts.Title: work the day after phone call of biopsy results lovewins lovewins

But for the nurse to tell you anything, is completely wrong. They are taught to never make a comment of any kind. Hoping for the best for you!
Posts.Title: Had Core Biopsy and Nurse Told it Doesn't look good bojoi7 ballet12

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2013 07:11PM dogsandjogs wrote: Just wanted to mention: My surgeon told me that a mastectomy isn't considered to be a painful surgery. And it wasn't for me --I think they gave me a couple of injections after the surgery/reconstruction, but after that I didn't need any pain killers at all!  I was very relieved as I am allergic to most of them.
Posts.Title: Need to make a decision...would like help from all of you... peace777 ruthbru

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2011 11:43AM dogsandjogs wrote: It is such an individual thing: I felt great after the lumpectomy; called my family and friends and talked, and talked (this was just a few hours afterwards) The next day I walked my 3 dogs, one at a time and still felt very energized. This weird energy lasted about 5 days, then I felt normal for another 3 weeks. In the last few days I've been unusually tired - fall asleep at 7 p.m. wake up at 4, 5 and 6 so can't get proper rest. I think it is a delayed reaction from the lumpectomy so have decided not to push it until I feel better. Don't push yourself, your body will tell you when you are ready to do more. Try to drink lots of water and don't eat too much sugar. I think sugar tires you because of the up-feeling you get and then the low feeling after an hour or so.
Posts.Title: Fatigue after lumpectomy, normal? BioAdoptMom3 Janney03

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2013 09:11AM dogsandjogs wrote: Mammograms are only 85 percent correct. Mammograms missed both my cancers; I found the lumps myself. That's why I am always telling everyone to check themselves on a monthly basis.
Posts.Title: Thought I'd be one of the 80% FrannyM424 sweetjam

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2014 01:12PM dogsandjogs wrote: I agree with Deb. There is a lot of support on these threads. Check thru some of them and you will see---- About your knee - I had something similar, fracture of the tibial plateau, torn meniscus, Baker's Cyst and very little cartilage left in my knee. I also had debris. The fracture healed, the meniscus (cartilage) you just have to deal with --the Baker's Cyst is not dangerous and also goes away in time.  The debris can be taken care of with a "scope" if it is painful. It comes from the bones rubbing against each other due to the lack of cartilage. I am now back to jogging, so try not to worry about the knee or the breast. Get out, talk to people, join a reading group,  it is not good to be by yourself so much.  Adopt a cat or a dog---- Wishing you the best ----
Posts.Title: sad, alone and confused Idunno Hortense

Try not to worry -

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2013 03:16PM dogsandjogs wrote: I don't see what else could have been done. The lymph node had to be removed to rule out lymphoma. I wouldn't worry so much about one lymph node.  I've had heard we have 200 all thru our bodies. The removal of one can't be that worrisome. You chances of getting LE is really small. I posted that I had 17 nodes removed years ago. Neither the doctor or anyone else told me about possible LE; they just said not to have BP taken on that side.  But now after so many years I don't worry about that. I also had just finished a marathon before my surgery so got back to running after 3 weeks. I did not baby the arm at all (since nobody had told me to do that) and I think the constant pumping of the arm during running probably kept me from getting LE.

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2011 01:38PM dogsandjogs wrote: Dreaming - I also had the Mohs surgery (on my nose) the PS did a pretty good job pulling the skin from my cheek to fill in the large crater formed when the cancer was taken out. Have a scar running down my nose, but since I have a lot of wrinkles anyway - it doesn't stand out that much. I have a lot of basal cell cancers due to teenage years when we all lived on the beach and slathered on baby oil!!!  Little did we know! PS  I was also told the skin cancers were not connected to breast cancer.
Posts.Title: How many years have you been a Survivor? IllinoisNancy Lou789

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2011 01:02PM dogsandjogs wrote: Apparently this is what they do nowadays; a biopsy, not surgery. Years ago I had surgery in the doctor's office for a suspicious lump which was cancer. Now they do all these tests - it is exhausting. The biopsy is no big deal. They numb you and I had no pain afterwards. Best of luck!
Posts.Title: core biopsy or surgery? vanlex SoCalLisa

Sure would like to skip the expense of the hospital. I will try to find a PS who will do it in the office. Piper Pete: My friend had a double mastectomy w/o reconstruction. She went back for some additional surgery due to extra skin, bumps etc. She said she looks nice and flat now.

She decided against the hormonals and is doing nothing further.  It is her decision and she doesn't want to influence anyone else. But she is feeling fine; her boyfriend is still around and her life is good.

It was a completely new cancer the onc said and the same size as the other one.

So now I'm counting again ---5 months so far!

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2011 01:33PM dogsandjogs wrote: She is probably tired from the stress - I sure was and also for several weeks after the surgery. So try to be positive around your Mom for her sake.
Posts.Title: Need help understanding mammo results.. worriednlost barbe1958

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2011 10:11AM dogsandjogs wrote: After I found my breast lump I called my internist. He advised me to see my ob/gyn which I did next day. The ob/gyn got me an appointment with the breast center where they did a mammogram and ultra sound. They then said they would be calling me to set up an appt. for a core biopsy (it could not be done that day) After the biopsy I then saw the breast surgeon who examined me, looked at the biopsy report and said his office would schedule the surgery. The whole thing took a long time as it was the holidays. I found the lump November 17 and had a lumpectomy Feb 8. But everyone assured me that the long wait would not matter as tumors grow very slowly.
Posts.Title: Do Breast Surgeons do anything at virst appointment kitty16 IllinoisNative

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2012 08:12PM dogsandjogs wrote: Just to add, both lumps are pretty small which is a good sign.
Posts.Title: Melting down over ultrasound report scaredinal scaredinal

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2011 08:34PM dogsandjogs wrote: Hope: Did you find a breast lump? Did you go to the doctor? What did he say? Did he recommend a biopsy to find out if it is breast cancer? Most lumps are not cancer. Please try not to worry so much.
Posts.Title: how painful mastectomy is and how do you cope up with it? h0petoBC Fearless_One

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2012 07:35PM dogsandjogs wrote: My first breast cancer was discovered after a biopsy in the surgeon's office. He called me five days later with the bad news. The second time, 28 years later, the breast cancer center told me to come back in two days for the biopsy result. At the breast center everyone has to come back to hear the news; whether it is good or bad. I was also told to bring someone with me in case the news was bad. But I didn't want to tell anyone until I was sure, so went by myself. By the way, I was told that breast cancer doesn't migrate to the other breast. If you get cancer in the opposite breast at a later date, it is considered a new cancer.

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2014 12:18PM dogsandjogs wrote: My guess is they will recommend  a lumpectomy which is not that bad. PS  Possibly they will do an ultrasound and maybe an MRI before the lumpectomy. I found my lump myself. Had a mammogram and an ultrasound. Then a few days later the MRI; but the MRI was only done because I had a lump in the opposite armpit (which turned out to be nothing) Then a biopsy and the following month (it was around the holidays; thus the delay) the lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2013 05:17PM dogsandjogs wrote: The radiologist said, "I don't know what it is" , when I asked if he thought it was a cancer after the mammo/ultrasound. I went to a breast center and they tell you to come in two days after the biopsy for the results. They also advise you to bring someone with you. I didn't because I hadn't told anyone about finding the lump . When I arrived an oncologist told me the news. I never saw the radiologist or the oncologist again and after the diagnosis the "navigator nurse" gave me a list of breast surgeons to check out. I then picked one and after the surgery picked out the oncologist

After I found out I then told family members and a few friends. Hang in there - stay busy - I cleaned house like mad after my first diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2012 10:15PM dogsandjogs wrote: Just discovered this thread. I found my first lump in 1982. In those days lumpectomies were just beginning to get popular - the doc didn't really trust them so advised me against it. I had a mastectomy with reconstruction. Then in November of 2011, on the VERY day that I had surgery in 1982, I discovered a lump in the other breast. Same size, same stage, same grade as the other one. The onc said it was a new primary, not a recurrence.  But I was still in shock - I had never worried about a NEW cancer; only about a recurrence. I skipped radiation due to my age, 76, and am thinking of quitting Aromasin due to very bad side effects.

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2011 09:36PM dogsandjogs wrote: My MIL had cancer in her 40s. The cancer came back in her bones 25 YEARS later. She had a mastectomy when the cancer was discovered, but no other procedures as this was many years ago. When her cancer returned she had chemo, and survived 5 years. I had a mastectomy 28 years ago. No other treatment was given.  I then got a NEW cancer in the other breast, not a recurrence. So I guess I could still get a recurrence from the first cancer and also the new one. You just never know---my surgeon says we all have embryonic cancer cells and if we knew what triggered them we would have a cure. But we don't.  He also said cancer cannot ever be said to be cured; it is in remission.

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2013 03:24AM dogsandjogs wrote: When I got the call, which I kind of expected as I had found the lump myself and  the surgeon had removed it in his office (this was in 1982 and that's what they did in those days) I was on vacation. That made it harder because I wasn't at my job so had little to distract me from the news.  So in order to feel "in control" I decided to clean house and get some repairs done. I even made arrangements to get a new roof!  Doing those types of things helped a lot. Then the following week I was back at work and going for tests off and on. The surgery (mastectomy and reconstruction) was done a week later. I was allowed to go back to work after 3 weeks.

He said it was up to me, so I declined.  My regular onc did not agree, but did not argue with me.
